header.title: The Study of Solomonic Magic in English
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Magic, Grimoire Traditions, Bibliography

central_thesis: This paper provides a structured bibliographic overview and analysis of texts belonging to the 'Solomonic cycle' of magic available in English, with a particular focus on medieval grimoires and their modern editions, translations, and online presence.

structure_content.summary: Discusses the difficulty in defining the 'Solomonic cycle' of magic, opting to include works bearing Solomon's name by tradition or artifice. Identifies two main classes: late antiquity/early Middle Ages magical works (e.g., The Testament of Solomon) and medieval grimoires (e.g., The Key of Solomon). Acknowledges Solomon's broader legend and the persistent rumors of his secret magical books.

Details two primary texts: The Key of Solomon and Lemegeton, or Lesser Key of Solomon. For The Key of Solomon, it highlights S.L. MacGregor Mathers' 'Key of Solomon the King' as the fullest presentation, along with treatments by Idries Shah and A.E. Waite. For Lemegeton, it describes its five sections: Goetia, Theurgia-Goetia, Pauline Art, Almadel, and Notary Art/Ars Nova. Discusses various editions of Goetia, including Mathers' and Crowley's, and mentions more complete editions of Lemegeton, notably Joseph H. Peterson's as the 'best edition available'.

Covers three major grimoires: Grimorium Verum, True Black Magic, and The Grand Grimoire. For Grimorium Verum, it references Waite and Shah, and notes editions by Trident Press and I.G.O.S. True Black Magic is described with conflicting accounts, noting Butler's description of talismans and Waite's view as an adapted, confused version of the Key, often quoted for practical elements. The Grand Grimoire (Red Dragon) is discussed through Waite and Shah, mentioning limited editions and dual-language versions.

Emphasizes the crucial distinction between the older Sworn Book of Honorius (Liber Iuratus) and the later, diabolical Grimoire of Pope Honorius. References Butler, Waite, and Shah for treatments of the Grimoire. Discusses Kineta Ch'ien's limited edition of The Grimoire of Pope Honorius and Daniel Driscoll's translation of The Sworn Book, noting its incompleteness, and the I.G.O.S. edition of 'Grimoire of Honorius' which aligns with the Sworn Book.

Describes S&S as a compilation drawing from various magical traditions, often found bound with The Sixth and Seventh Books of Moses. Notes its availability in editions from Egyptian Publishing Company, Wehman Brothers, and Migene Gonzolez-Wippler. Traces its historical roots to German collections by J.C. Horst and Scheibel, and notes its close textual parallels with Liber Salomonis.

structure_content.chapter_title: Liber Salomonis, British Library Sloane MS 3826
structure_content.summary: Provides a detailed account of Liber Salomonis, identifying it as folio pages 2r-57r of British Library Sloane MS 3826. Notes its self-identification as 'Cephar Raziel' and its narrative positioning of Solomon as the recipient rather than author. Outlines its seven treatises, covering astronomy, virtues of stones/herbs/beasts, suffumigations, timings for operations, abstinence, 'Samaim' (heavens and angels), and magical figures/ordinances. Also lists additional texts within Sloane MS 3826, including Incipit Canon, Orisons, Magical directions, Liber Lunae, and Raxhael.

Compiles a list of academic and occult literature that references British Library Sloane MS 3826. This includes works by Robert Mathiesen, M. Plessner, Idries Shah (Oriental Magic, The Secret Lore of Magic), Lynn Thorndike, and A.E. Waite (Book of Black Magic and of Pacts, The Book of Ceremonial Magic), highlighting its status as a significant source for the Sworn Book and Sefer Raziel.

Presents an extensive bibliography of other significant works related to magic, occultism, and esotericism, providing broader context for the study of Solomonic traditions. This section includes influential texts like Agrippa's 'Of Occult Philosophy', Barrett's 'The Magus', Butler's 'Ritual Magic', and scholarly works on the history of magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: Addendum: Solomonic Magic on the Internet
structure_content.summary: Offers a practical guide to online resources for Solomonic texts, categorized by the earlier sections (Clavicles, Grimoires, Honorius, S&S, Liber Salomonis). Highlights key websites like Twilit Grotto (www.esotericarchives.com), Sacred Texts Archive (www.sacred-texts.com), and Norton's Imperium (http://w3.one.net/~browe) for accessing texts, facsimiles, and transcriptions, often noting their origins from print sources.

key_concepts.definition: A loosely defined canon of magical texts traditionally attributed to or associated with King Solomon, encompassing both ancient magical works and medieval grimoires.
A textbook of magic, typically from the medieval or early modern period, that provides instructions for summoning spirits (demons or angels), creating magical tools, and performing various rituals.
A foundational Solomonic grimoire that serves as a primary source for many later works, often compiled from multiple manuscripts and detailing various magical operations.

key_concepts.term: Lemegeton, or Lesser Key of Solomon
key_concepts.definition: A composite grimoire divided into five distinct sections: Goetia (demon invocation), Theurgia-Goetia, Pauline Art, Almadel, and Notary Art (or Ars Nova).
The first and most widely known section of the Lemegeton, primarily concerned with the invocation and commanding of seventy-two demons for various magical purposes.

The fifth book of the Lemegeton, often debated regarding its content and inclusion, focused on acquiring knowledge, memory, and academic proficiency through prayer and visions rather than spirit invocation.

A significant British Library manuscript referred to as 'Cephar Raziel' or 'booke of Raziel' in the text, containing seven distinct treatises on various aspects of magic, including astronomy, virtues of natural items, suffumigations, timing, abstinence, celestial hierarchies, and magical figures.
An older and distinct magical text, often confused with the later 'Grimoire of Honorius', focused on higher magical operations and considered a foundational text in some traditions.

practical_system.description: The paper itself does not present a practical magical system, but rather surveys and analyzes texts that contain such systems. It acts as a guide to various Solomonic grimoires, which are operative manuals detailing procedures for spirit invocation, talisman creation, and other magical workings. The systems described within these texts typically involve specific preparatory rites, invocations, sigils, and correspondences.
tools: Talismans and pentacles with specific sigils
Books of spells and invocations (grimoires themselves)
rituals: Invocation and commanding of spirits (demons, angels, elementals)
Creation and consecration of talismans and magical characters
Rituals for acquiring knowledge, invisibility, love, healing, or other specific outcomes
Rites involving specific timing based on astrological considerations (e.g., Liber Salomonis's 'Treatise of tymes')
Purification and abstinence rituals (e.g., 'Treatise of Cleanesse' in Liber Salomonis)

relevant_quotes.text: It is impossible to neatly circumscribe a canon of magic texts as being safely of the 'Solomonic cycle.' By arbitrary and rather unscientific means, one might do so by simply including those works which, by tradition or artifice, bear Solomon's name or derive from works which do. Even here, we find at least two classes of material:

To Butler's basic list, a couple of items will be added. The classes and selections of the Solomonic cycle according to Butler are 1. The Clavicles (Keys) a. The Key of Solomon b. Lemegeton, or Lesser Key of Solomon 2. The Grimoires a. Grimorium Verum b. True Black Magic c. The Grand Grimoire 3. Honorius a. The Grimoire of Honorius b. Liber iuratus

Goetia is the best circulated of the sections, having been published numerous times. The best-known version is the one transcribed by S.L. MacGregor Mathers in 1898, with an introduction entitled 'Preliminary Definition of Magic.'
Peterson's is by far the best edition available.

Indeed, my initial advice to anyone interested in pursuing this material is to go to Twilit Grotto at www.esotericarchives.com where most of the items discussed below, along with a wealth of other texts, are responsibly and tastefully presentedâ€”and can be viewed for free.

critical_analysis.relevance: This paper is highly relevant for anyone studying or practicing Solomonic magic, Western Esotericism, or the history of grimoires. It provides a comprehensive, structured bibliography of key texts in English, clarifying distinctions between works, evaluating different editions, and offering practical guidance to both print and online resources. Its detailed descriptions of manuscripts and their contents are invaluable for academic researchers and dedicated practitioners seeking to understand the lineage and practical mechanics of these magical traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes academic researchers in religious studies, history, and esotericism; occult practitioners interested in grimoire traditions; bibliophiles and collectors of esoteric literature; and students or enthusiasts seeking a reliable guide to Solomonic magical texts.
